title: Learning from Complexity: Enabling Governance Frameworks
abstractText:
This pilot study examines in detail a case study company using complexity theory as a lens to focus on governance frameworks. The relationships between internal and external actors to a corporation are dynamic and liable to change. The internal actors include directors and employees whilst the external actors include, inter alia, investors, and bodies representing legal, regulatory and capital market frameworks. 

Using an innovative approach of complexity theory to study the case study company, the research seeks to identify the companyâ€™s various internal and external actors and to map the dynamics between them. Such dynamics include the co-evolution of actors vis a vis each other, a concept which is central to complexity theory.

The in-depth analysis of actor relationships with the case study company is likely to highlight hitherto undiscovered dynamics and inform investors and policy makers as to whether current corporate governance mechanisms and legal frameworks are adequate and if not, how they may be re-shaped or adjusted. In so doing, research questions may also be framed as to whether an appropriate position can be reached given the traditional regulatory rationales, and any new actor relationship dynamics with the corporation discovered using complexity theory.
